result.text:
I'm heartbroken. Charlie Kirk passing away is a hard pill to swallow. 

I never imagined typing this out, 
it hurts so much. Things will never be the same without him. 

He was a great friend to me, he treated me like a brother, opened doors for me and so many others and inspired us all with his unwavering spirit. 

He leaves behind two kids and a wife who he cherished deeply. 

Charlie was a great American, fighting for what he believed in every day. 

Rest in peace, brother. üíî

result.text: ha! here is something fun and totally random I've been pondering: as Oliver Sacks has beautifully written - "what is the space between two snowflakes?" Language can describe all the things, stuff, and people in intricate details. But what about the 'space', the 'nothingness' in between all of them? Without this 'nothingness', space doesn't exist, and things to move. The elegant path a butterfly took from one flower to another is as curious and intriguing as the fact the butterfly has landed on a flower...

result.text:
Incredibly powerful Claude Code prompt when dealing with a pesky bug:

I am experiencing the following bug:

<bug>
[explain_bug_here]
</bug>

I need your help to identify the exact cause of this bug and implement an effective solution. To do this, carefully follow the workflow below, in this specific order:

Workflow:

Step 1: Clarification (if needed)
- If any part of this prompt is unclear or confusing, ask clarifying questions before proceeding.
- Do not ask questions unnecessarily‚Ä¶ only ask if essential information is missing.

Step 2: Deeply Understand the Issue (Ultrathink)
- Carefully review and analyze the entire relevant codebase.
- Trace through the code step-by-step until you fully understand the bug and all relevant context.
- Continue analyzing until you feel completely confident in your understanding. If in doubt, research more deeply. It‚Äôs better to over-research than under-research.

Step 3: Special Case (if the cause is extremely obvious)
- If, after completing Step 2, you identify the root cause with extremely high confidence (95%+ certainty), explicitly state this clearly. Be realistic here. Do NOT be overconfident.
- In this scenario, instead of generating unrelated causes (see below for context), propose multiple practical variations of fixes for this single, clearly identified cause.
- Then proceed directly to Step 7 (Implementation), creating separate sub-agents and git worktrees for each variation, and implementing each fix independently.

Step 4: Identify Possible Causes (if cause is not extremely obvious)
- Thoughtfully generate a comprehensive list of at least 20 plausible causes for the bug.
- Be thorough. Explore various angles, even ones that initially seem less likely.

Step 5: Refine and Prioritize Causes
- Carefully review your list from Step 4.
- Remove theories that don‚Äôt hold up upon closer analysis.
- Combine related or overlapping theories into clearer, more likely scenarios.
- Add any additional theories you may have initially missed.
- Clearly rewrite and finalize this refined list.

Step 6: Rank by Likelihood
- Rank your refined theories clearly and explicitly, ordering them from most likely to least likely based on the probability of each theory being the true root cause.

Step 7: Propose Solutions
- For each of the top 10 most likely causes, clearly outline a practical and actionable solution to fix the issue.

Step 8: Implement Solutions Using Sub-agents
- For each of these top 10 cause/solution pairs (or multiple variations in the Special Case scenario), create a separate sub-agent, each with its own git worktree.
- Each sub-agent should clearly understand the specific cause it‚Äôs addressing and implement the corresponding solution directly in its own git worktree.

Step 9: Test the Solutions
- If testing each solution is possible given your available resources, perform tests (one worktree at a time) to determine if the bug is fixed.
- ‚ÄúPossible‚Äù means you have the appropriate tools and resources (e.g., a CURL command for API bugs; browser access for frontend bugs).
- If testing is not possible due to resource limitations, clearly summarize the implemented solutions and provide explicit, step-by-step instructions for me to test each solution manually.

‚∏ª

Please carefully and thoughtfully complete every step of this workflow, maintaining clear communication throughout. Keep me updated at each major step, but only pause if you encounter something that requires my input.

legacy.full_text:
This is the chaos produced by a triple pendulum with just 3 degrees of freedom.

Your hand has 27: 4 per finger + 5 for the thumb + 6 for the wrist

Building a robot to conduct this orchestra of joints and tendons to pick up a coin is ... non-trivial. https://t.co/PGOUeYTOZd

Designing dexterous hands for robots is a very hard problem. 

Then figuring out how to manufacture them at scale is 100 times harder.

legacy.description: Deep dive into everything Tesla

result.text:
Summary of @elonmusk‚Äôs 44 minute interview at the @allinsummit:

Government: 
‚Ä¢ Elon hasn‚Äôt been back to DC since May, ‚ÄúThe Government is basically unfixable.‚Äù
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúIf AI & Robots don‚Äôt solve the National Debt, we‚Äôre toast.‚Äù

Optimus:
‚Ä¢ Tesla is finalizing the design of Optimus Gen 3. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be a very remarkable robot.‚Äù
‚Ä¢ Optimus Gen 3 will have the manual dexterity of a human. 
‚Ä¢ Optimus Gen 3 will have an AI mind that can navigate, and comprehend reality. 
‚Ä¢ There is no supply chain for humanoid robots, Tesla is making everything from scratch. It requires a lot of vertical integration.
‚Ä¢ All of Optimus‚Äô actuators are made in-house by Tesla. There are 26 actuators, per arm. 
‚Ä¢ Elon reiterates: ‚ÄúIf Optimus is successful, it will be the biggest product, ever.‚Äù
‚Ä¢ Production Cost of Optimus, once 1M units/year are achieved is around the $20,000 range. 
‚Ä¢ The AI chip for Optimus will be expensive, potentially $5-6K , maybe more. 
‚Ä¢ Price of Optimus will be a function of demand. 
‚Ä¢ Tesla had to design Optimus‚Äô every electric motor, gearbox, and the controlling electronics from scratch. 
‚Ä¢ Creating Optimus is harder than making Model S/3/X/Y/CT, but not harder than Starship. 
‚Ä¢ The forearms and hands of Optimus are majoirty of engineering difficulties of the entire robot. 
‚Ä¢ Optimus LLM will be included, no added subscription. 

AI4, AI5, AI6 & FSD:
‚Ä¢ Tesla is currently finalizing the design for AI5. It will be an immense jump from AI4. 
‚Ä¢ AI5 will be 40x better than AI4 in some metrics. 
‚Ä¢ Tesla is working so closely on the AI Hardware, and Software this time around. Both teams are co-designing the chip. 
‚Ä¢ AI5 has 8x more commute than AI4. 
‚Ä¢ AI5 has 10x more memory than AI4.
‚Ä¢ AI5 has 5x more memory-bandwidth than AI4.
‚Ä¢ Elon is confident AI4 chips will still be able to achieve self-driving safety that is at least 2-3x of a human, maybe even 10x. 
‚Ä¢ FSD 14 will be released in a few months.
‚Ä¢ V14 will be the biggest upgrade to Tesla‚Äôs software since V12. 
‚Ä¢ FSD 14 will make the car feel sentient, by the end of the year. 

Starlink:
‚Ä¢ New spectrum deal will allow SpaceX to deliver high-bandwidth connectivity directly from the satellites, to the phone. 
‚Ä¢ Current frequencies aren‚Äôt supported in current phones. Hardware changes are needed.
‚Ä¢ Chipsets need to be modified to add the new frequencies.
‚Ä¢ The phones capable of using this new frequency will ship in two years. 
‚Ä¢ You will be able to watch videos anywhere in the world.
‚Ä¢ These frequencies required will work inside a building, it won‚Äôt cut off. 
‚Ä¢ You will be able to have a Starlink Account instead of a Verizon/At&T account, but it won‚Äôt put other carriers out of business. 
‚Ä¢ SpaceX may buy carriers to gain more spectrum. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not out the question, it may happen.‚Äù 

Starship:
‚Ä¢ SpaceX will recover Starship starting next year.
‚Ä¢ There is only one V2 Starship left. 
‚Ä¢ V3 is a radical re-design, initially it might go through some teething pains. 
‚Ä¢ V3 is capable of over 100T to orbit, fully reusable.
‚Ä¢ Starting in 2026, SpaceX will demonstrate fully reusability next year, catching both booster and ship. 
‚Ä¢ Elon thinks a self-sustaining life on Mars can be achieved within roughly 25 years. 

AI:
‚Ä¢ A rough rule of thumb is 10x more compute will double the intelligence. 
‚Ä¢ Elon thinks we will continue to see intelligence scale all the way up to where most of the power of the sun is harnessed for compute. 
‚Ä¢ Human Intelligence is currently plateauing due to low birth-rates and population declines. It will eventually start declining. 
‚Ä¢ Elon guesses AI will be smarter than absolutely everything starting next year.
‚Ä¢ By 2030, Elon guesses AI will be smarter than the sum of ALL humans.

   1. ‰∫íÂä®ÊåáÊ†á (Engagement Signals):
       * ÁÇπËµû (Likes), ÂõûÂ§ç (Replies), ËΩ¨Êé® (Retweets):
         ËøôÊòØÊúÄÊ†∏ÂøÉÁöÑÁßØÊûÅ‰ø°Âè∑„ÄÇ‰∏ÄÊù°Êé®ÊñáÂú®Áü≠Êó∂Èó¥ÂÜÖËé∑ÂæóÁöÑ‰∫íÂä®Ë∂äÂ§öÔºåÁÆóÊ≥ïÂ∞±Ë∂ä‰ºöËÆ§‰∏∫ÂÆÉÊòØÈ´òË¥®ÈáèÁöÑÔºåÂπ∂Â∞ÜÂÖ∂Êé®ËçêÁªôÊõ¥Â§ö‰∫∫„ÄÇ

       * ÁÇπÂáªÁéá (Click-through Rate): Â¶ÇÊûú‰Ω†ÁöÑÊé®ÊñáÂåÖÂê´ÈìæÊé•„ÄÅÂõæÁâáÊàñËßÜÈ¢ëÔºåÁî®Êà∑ÁÇπÂáªÊü•ÁúãÁöÑÊØî‰æãË∂äÈ´òÔºåÊùÉÈáç‰πüË∂äÈ´ò„ÄÇ
